revision.text:
'''Ves Peterburg''' (/vʲesʲ pʲɪtʲɪrˈburg/; in 1914–1923 '''Ves Petrograd'''; in 1924–1940 '''Ves Leningrad''' — the annual [[city directory]] of [[Saint Petersburg|Petersburg–Petrograd–Leningrad]] started in 1894 by [[Aleksei Sergeevich Suvorin]] (1834–1912) in [[Russian Empire]], continued by his descendants up to 1917 and resumed in 1922 by [[Lensovet]], the soviet city authorities of [[Leningrad]], up to 1935<ref name="Vexler">''Veksler A. F.'' [http://www.encspb.ru/en/article.php?kod=2804017249 Ves Peterburg (Entire St. Petersburg)]</ref>.
The full name of the edition is {{lang-ru|Весь Петербург/Петроград/Ленинград. Адресная и справочная книга г. Петербурга/Петрограда/Ленинграда}} where the subtitle clarifies and discloses that this directory contains addresses and the other reference information for the city. Actually this huge volume which grew up to 1800-1900 pages has always provided more, including surveys on the city economy, extracts from the legislative acts, lists of the post offices through the entire Russia, if not to mention thousands of commercial advertisings.
A point of special interest was the historic and statistical city digest in V. I. Pokrovsky's feature article, published in the Ves Peterburg in 1901 and 1903)<ref name="Vexler" />.
From 1910-ths the editors of the directory aimed at the gradual expansion of the territorial coverage of their edition. Starting with the closest suburbs, by 1917 they included the information and maps related to the largest cities of the Petrograd gubernia. After the soviets resumed the publication of the city directory, they continued this expansion, covering more and more cities of the [[Leningrad oblast]], up to [[Luga, Leningrad Oblast|Luga]] and [[Gdov]].
== Structure == === Governmental institutions === Until 1917, while the city was the capital of the Russian empire, 'Ves Petrograd' provided its readers with the comprehensive information upon the ministries and the councils, the royal establishments and the State Duma. The movement of the capital of the Soviet Russia from Petrograd to Moscow in 1918 coinsided with the 4-year suspension of the directory (1918-1921).
Since 1922 when the city authorities of Petrograd resumed the publication of the directory, it continued the institutional section of the directory, now revealing the new structure of the municipal (soviets), party committees, professional unions and other social organizations.
=== Cultural, educational, religious and other non-commercial institutions=== In different periods the relevant information was either included in the first, 'governmental' section, or was concentrated in trhe separate section of the directory. It's noteworthy to mention, that since the very first editions of the Soviet period, 'Ves Leningrad' has been publishing the list of cathedrals and churches, which were taken under the state protection, as the cultural monuments. From 1920-ies the directories contain a lot information on people education, which help historians to trace its development from the [[likbez]] schools for illiterate to many hundreds of schools and tens of universities opened by the end of the First Five-year plan (1927-1932) and later.
=== Commercial institutions, industry and finance === The entries of this section are usually repeated in two subsections, alphabetic by name and by the branch of industry. Alongside with thousands of separate commercial advertisings, it provides economic historians with the valuable source of raw data. Beyond that, the directory published the special surveys on the city economy, including the turnover of the international trade, where Leningrad played the main role, as the largest port in the USSR.
Those who imagine the Leningrad as the core of the strict government-run economy shall be surprised to see tens, if not hundreds of small collectively owned guilds (artel {{lang-ru|артели}}) and cooperatives which continued to function in Leningrad many years after the NEP (the 'new economic policy') was suspended in favour of the 5-year planning.
=== Doctors, lawyers, etc. === The personal lists of practitioners in medicine and advocacy are the characteristic feature of the epoch before second world war. One should not be surprised to find hundreds of private lawyers, dentists and even obstetricians in Petrograd and Leningrad, for the soviet economy has never been totally government-run.
=== Streets and lists of residents === This is a very important section for the directory of the city like Leningrad, counting 2-3 million residents. The special section of the directory not only lists all the streets in alphabetic order, but also informs, what house numbers are on the odd and even sides between the crossing streets. If necessary, special maps are provided for the longest streets and prospects. Alongside with the house numbers the directory informs about the jurisdiction of the relevant city blocks, the closest post offices etc.
Amateur researchers often fall into error, mussing up the ownership of the real estates with the personal residential addresses, however the professional historians extract deeper information, differing between the owners and the managers. However, 70% and more of the pre-revolutionary residents of Petrograd, mainly industrial workers remained outside the directory, since they were economically forced to hire separate rooms, and even the corners of rooms, offered to them by the wholesale profiteers in hiring dwellings. Also, even in the middle class families only the heads of households were listed in the directory, while their spouses and minors were omitted.
Anyway, the curious scrollers may be excided to find online not only the addresses, but also the home telephone numbers of [[Matilda Kshesinskaya]]<ref>[https://vivaldi.nlr.ru/bx000020513/view#page=1115 Кшесинская Матильда Феликсовна]. — Весь Петербург, 1913.</ref> (#414), [[Aleksandr Kerensky]] (#11-960<ref>[https://vivaldi.nlr.ru/bx000020513/view#page=1050 Керенский Александр Фёдорович] — Весь Петербург, 1913.</ref>) on the pages of 'Ves Peterburg', as well as of [[Grigory Zinoviev]] (#127-61<ref>[https://vivaldi.nlr.ru/bx000020124/view#page=641 Зиновьев Григорий Евсеевич]. — Весь Ленинград, 1924.</ref>) on the pages of 'Ves Leningrad'.
=== Public transport === In 1970s Leningrad became the top-ranking city of the world by the length of city tram lines and the total number of tram routes. From the directory of 1908, after the first lines of tram were opened (September, 1907), the directory provided the detailed information on each of these routes, including the streets, the tram stops, the fares, and what is not less important, the specific combination of colored identification lights which were set for each tram route.
== Termination of series == The last directory of 'Ves Leningrad' was published in 1935<ref>[http://nlr.ru/cont/v_l/1935.php Весь Ленинград], 1935.</ref>. In the subsequent years the edition was replaced with abridged version (1939 and 1940) where all personal data (residency / domicile, phone numbers) was excluded.
== Other city directories ==
Suvorin also published city directories for [[Moscow]] under the title ''[[Vsia Moskva]]'' (All Moscow) for the years 1875 to 1936 and for the whole country under the titles ''[[Vsia Rossiia]]'' (All Russia) continued under than name ''[[Ves SSSR]]'' (All USSR) from 1924 to 1931.
Since 1993 the private publishing House Presskom launched the annual telephone directory project under the title 'Ves Petersburg', however it is radically and conceptually different from its historical predecessor, and does not list residents at all<ref name="Vexler" />.
== Sources == * ''Veksler A. F.'' [http://www.encspb.ru/en/article.php?kod=2804017249 Ves Peterburg (Entire St. Petersburg)]
==See also==
*''[[Vsia Moskva]]'' *''[[Vsia Rossiia]]''
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
== External links == *[http://www.nlr.ru Official website of the Russian National Library in Saint Petersburg]

revision.comment: The page was vandalized with misleading information about Wanderu's services.
revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Wanderu | logo = Wanderu-logo-stacked.jpg | type = Private | area_served = [[North America]]
[[Europe]] | key_people = Polina Raygorodskaya, [[Chief Executive Officer|CEO]]
Igor A Bratnikov, [[Chief Operating Officer|COO]] | industry = [[Travel]]
[[Technology]] | num_employees = 25+ | foundation = 2012 | location = [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]], [[United States]] | homepage = {{URL|www.wanderu.com}} }} '''Wanderu''' is a ground travel search platform and [[Travel website#Fare aggregators and metasearch engines|fare aggregator]] that operates throughout [[North America]] and [[Europe]]. It partners with bus and train operators to provide a one-stop search and booking platform through its website and mobile app. Wanderu is headquartered in [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]]. The company was founded in 2012 by CEO Polina Raygorodskaya and COO Igor Bratnikov.{{cite web|url=http://www.crunchbase.com/company/wanderu|title=Wanderu | CrunchBase Profile|date=|publisher=Crunchbase.com|accessdate=2013-04-30}} == History == === Foundation === Wanderu was founded in 2012 by Polina Raygorodskaya and Igor Bratnikov. At the time when the idea for Wanderu was conceived, Raygorodskaya and Bratnikov were part of [[GreenXC]], a nationwide campaign intended to raise awareness for national parks and forests throughout the [[United States]].{{cite web|url=http://blogs.usda.gov/2011/07/07/us-forest-service-helps-young-adults-bring-awareness-to-national-forests-though-a-cross-country-adventure/|title=USDA Blog » US Forest Service Helps Young Adults Bring Awareness to National Forests Though a Cross-Country Adventure|date=|publisher=Blogs.usda.gov|author=Polina says:|accessdate=2013-04-30}} Aiming to promote sustainable forms of transportation, the group chose ride-shares as their main form of travel hitting a snag when one of their ride-shares cancelled and they had to find a bus to get to their next destination. Since no direct bus served the route, they had no way of finding which buses could get them where they needed to go or even find the closest station to where they were. Realizing the void in the market, they set out to build Wanderu.{{cite web|url=http://www.budgettravel.com/blog/about-to-enter-golden-age-ground-transportation,12604/|title=Is the Golden Age of Ground Transportation Near? | Budget Travel's Blog | Travel Deals, Travel Tips, Travel Advice, Vacation Ideas|last=Michonski|first=Laura|date=2012-11-07|publisher=Budgettravel.com|accessdate=2013-04-30}} In May 2013, Wanderu launched a private beta version of Wanderu. In August 2013, the company raised $2.45 million in a seed round of funding from a group of investors, including Alta Ventures Mexico, Wasabi Ventures, Drummond Road Capital, former [[Greyhound Lines|Greyhound]] CEO Craig Lentzsch, Jeffrey Clarke, Bill Kaplan, [[Semyon Dukach]], and Oliver Thylmann. On August 12, 2013, Wanderu.com was officially launched to the public, covering bus and train travel within the [[Northeastern United States|Northeast]].{{Cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2014/11/06/just-in-time-for-the-car-less-generation-bus-and-train-ticket-aggregator-wanderu-raises-5-6m-series-a/|title=Just In Time For The Car-Less Generation, Bus And Train Ticket Aggregator Wanderu Raises $5.6M Series A|last=Perez|first=Sarah|website=TechCrunch|access-date=2017-02-01}} === Growth in North America === In May 2014, Wanderu announced a partnership with [[Greyhound Lines|Greyhound]], the largest bus travel provider in the [[United States]]. As a result, Wanderu acquired nationwide coverage.{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/alextaub/2014/05/22/travel-startup-wanderu-lands-a-partnership-with-greyhound/#eb387bf29c03|title=Travel Startup Wanderu Lands A Partnership With Greyhound|last=Taub|first=Alexander|newspaper=Forbes|access-date=2017-02-03}} In November 2014, Wanderu completed a [[Series A round|Series A]] round of funding, raising $5.6 million. The round featured 10 [[investor]]s, including Alta Ventures Mexico, [[500 Startups]], [[Barbara Corcoran]] Venture Partners, [[Compound (company)|Compound]], Drummond Road Capital, Marc Bell Ventures, Klingenstein, Fields & Co, Craig Lentzsch, [[Brad Feld]], and Kiril Bensonoff. In February 2015, Wanderu released a [[Mobile app|smartphone application]] for [[iOS]] devices, followed by the release an [[Android (operating system)|Android]] version in March 2015.{{Cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/02/12/wanderu-lets-you-book-bus-and-train-tickets-from-your-iphone/|title=Wanderu Lets You Book Bus And Train Tickets From Your iPhone|last=Perez|first=Sarah|website=TechCrunch|access-date=2017-02-01}}{{Cite web|url=http://mashable.com/2015/05/06/wanderu-app-android/|title=Wanderu launches Android app for bus and train booking in the U.S.|last=Plautz|first=Jessica|website=Mashable|access-date=2017-02-01}} In April 2015, Wanderu signed a partnership with [[Amtrak]], the largest passenger inter-city [[Rail transport|railroad]] service in the United States. As a result, Wanderu’s coverage increased to over 90% of the U.S. that is reachable by ground.{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/travel/roadwarriorvoices/2015/04/29/bus-and-train-travel-comparison-site-wanderu-announces-partnership-with-amtrak/83077854/|title=Bus and train travel comparison site Wanderu announces partnership with Amtrak|newspaper=USA TODAY|language=en|access-date=2017-02-01}} In November 2015, Wanderu partnered with bus companies [[Grupo Senda]] and [[TUFESA|Tufesa]] to offer trips to multiple destinations across [[Mexico]], as well as options for [[cross-border]] travel between Mexico and the United States.{{Cite news|url=https://www.wanderu.com/blog/wanderu-turimex-bus-from-usa-to-mexico/|title=Wanderu Expands Partnership with Turimex Internacional - Wanderu|date=2015-11-18|newspaper=Wanderu|language=en-US|access-date=2017-02-01}} In February 2016, Wanderu announced a partnership with [[Via Rail|VIA Rail]], an intercity passenger rail service in [[Canada]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.wanderu.com/blog/wanderu-canada-train-travel-via-rail-partnership/|title=Wanderu Partners with Leading Canadian Train Travel Provider VIA Rail - Wanderu|date=2016-02-10|newspaper=Wanderu|language=en-US|access-date=2017-02-01}} === Expansion to Europe === In January 2017, Wanderu expanded into [[Europe]], launching service to more than 1,000 destinations across more than 20 countries, including [[Germany]], [[France]], [[Austria]], [[Belgium]], [[Netherlands|the Netherlands]], [[Switzerland]], and [[United Kingdom|the United Kingdom]], among other places.{{Cite news|url=http://www.travelandleisure.com/travel-tips/ground-transportation/wanderu-europe|title=Find Cheap Train and Bus Fares Across Europe|newspaper=Travel + Leisure|access-date=2017-02-01}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.wanderu.com/blog/wanderu-bus-train-travel-launches-in-europe/|title=Bus & Train Travel Search Platform Wanderu Launches in Europe|date=2017-01-25|newspaper=Wanderu|language=en-US|access-date=2017-02-01}} In Europe, Wanderu partners with some of the biggest bus and train travel providers, including [[Flixbus|FlixBus]], [[OUIBUS|Ouibus]], and [[National Express]]. About 160 additional carriers are currently being integrated into the search engine. == Recognition == Wanderu was a finalist of [[MassChallenge]] in the summer of 2012{{cite web|url=http://masschallenge.org/profile/wanderu |title=Wanderu |publisher=MassChallenge |date=2011-09-22 |accessdate=2013-04-30}} and an original member of [[PayPal]]'s Start Tank in Boston.{{cite web|author=Home Job Board Blogs Deals Networking Calendar Directory |url=http://venturefizz.com/blog/recap-paypal-and-stubhubs-office-opening-event |title=Recap from PayPal & StubHub's Office Opening Event [slideshow |publisher=VentureFizz |date=2013-03-01 |accessdate=2013-04-30}} In February 2013, Wanderu won the [[South by Southwest]] Accelerator Grand Prize in the Innovative Web Technology category.{{Cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/boston/blog/startups/2013/03/wanderu-wins-at-sxsw-for-innovative-web.html|title=Wanderu wins at SXSW for Innovative Web|last=Alspach|first=Kyle|date=|website=www.bizjournals.com|publisher=|access-date=2017-02-01}} In February 2015, Wanderu a top 3 finalist at [[Richard Branson|Sir Richard Branson]]’s Extreme Tech Challenge.{{Cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/boston/blog/startups/2015/01/wanderu-named-finalist-in-richard-bransonstartup.html|title=Wanderu named finalist in Richard Branson startup challenge|last=|first=|date=|website=www.bizjournals.com|publisher=|access-date=2017-02-01}} [[Time (magazine)|TIME]] named the Wanderu app as one of its favorite [[iPhone]] apps,{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/3714747/iphone-apps-snl/|title=These Are Our Favorite iPhone Apps of the Week|website=Time|access-date=2017-02-01}} [[USA Today]] named it one of the top budget travel apps of 2015,{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/travel/advice/2015/11/02/10best-readers-choice-budget-travel-winners/75028282/|title=10Best Readers' Choice: Best of budget travel|newspaper=USA TODAY|language=en|access-date=2017-02-01}} and [[CNET|CNet]] called it one of the best apps for booking travel.{{Cite web|url=http://download.cnet.com/blog/download-blog/best-apps-for-booking-travel/|title=Best apps for booking travel {{!}} The Download Blog - CNET Download.com|website=download.cnet.com|access-date=2017-02-01}} In April 2015, Polina Raygorodskaya and Igor Bratnikov were featured in [[Inc. (magazine)|Inc. Magazine]]’s annual Top 30 Under 30 Coolest [[Entrepreneurship|Entrepreneurs]] list.{{Cite news|url=http://www.inc.com/donna-fenn/2015-30-under-30-wanderu.html|title=The Bus Business and How Wanderu Is Getting Millennials on Board|date=2017-04-22|newspaper=Inc.com|language=en|access-date=2017-02-01}} In October 2015, Polina Raygorordskaya was featured by [[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]] as one of 40 Under 40 Women to Watch.{{Cite web|url=http://fortune.com/2015/10/28/40-under-40-women-watch/|title=Women to Watch|website=Fortune|access-date=2017-02-01}} In January 2016, Polina Raygorodskaya and Igor Bratnikov were featured in [[Forbes]]’ annual 30 Under 30 list in the Consumer Tech category.{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/30-under-30-2016/consumer-tech/#7d05149177d2|title=30 Under 30 2016: Consumer Tech|website=Forbes|access-date=2017-02-01}} In November 2016, Inc. Magazine named Wanderu one of the top 15 companies of 2016.{{Cite news|url=http://www.inc.com/graham-rapier/wanderu-2016-company-of-the-year-nominee.html|title=This Startup Wants to Drag Bus Travel Out of the Dark Ages--and It Just Might|date=2016-11-16|newspaper=Inc.com|language=en|access-date=2017-02-01}} == References == {{reflist}} == External links == *{{Official website|www.wanderu.com}} {{Travel ticket search engines}} [[Category:Companies based in Suffolk County, Massachusetts]] [[Category:Comparison shopping websites]] [[Category:Computer companies of the United States]] [[Category:Internet properties established in 2011]] [[Category:Online retailers of the United States]] [[Category:Organizations based in Boston]] [[Category:Route planning software]] [[Category:Software companies based in Massachusetts]] [[Category:Travel technology]] [[Category:Travel ticket search engines]] [[Category:Travel websites]]
